statement:
In a metric space $X$, let $\overline{B}_{r}(x)$ be the closed ball
centered at $x\in X$ with radius $r>0$.

A metric space $X$ is complete if and only if every sequence
$\{\overline B_{r_n}(x_n)\}_n$ such that
$\overline B_{r_{i+1}}(x_{i+1}) \subseteq \overline B_{r_i}(x_i)$ and
$r_n \to 0$ when $n \to \infty$ has a nonempty intersection *(i.e.
$\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}\overline B_{r_n}(x_n) \neq \emptyset$)*.

[1]{} Kolmogorov, A.N. & Fomin, S.V.: Introductory Real Analysis,
Translated & Edited by Richard A. Silverman. Dover Publications, Inc.
New York, 1970.
